moves.1. e4: This is what passes for my opening repertoire. Not very original huh? I like this game because although I gave up a large advantage I gained early. I finished with a very pretty forced mate.
moves.1... e5 2. Nf3 d5 3. Nxe5: I won't play exd5 because of e4, threatening my knight.
moves.3... d4: Letting go of the e-file for the sake of an advanced d pawn.
moves.4. g3: I want to fianchetto my white bishop.
moves.5. Nf3 c5: This lets me know he doesn't have any immediate plans to lose another pawn so I might as well release my good bishop.
moves.6. d3 b6: I'm sure I would pay dearly for delaying development if my opponent weren't also pushing pawns.
moves.12... Nb4: Black almost had a good attack, he should have simply protected the d pawn.
moves.13. Bxd4: And I didn't see what was coming.
moves.14... Nc2: A rook for a bishop and a knight I'll take.
moves.15. Qxd3 Nxe1 16. Nxe1: And I win the exchange (this game helped me recognize the superiority of a bishop and a knight against a rook in many positions)
moves.17. Nc3: stops the threat to the knight while releasing my rook.
moves.17... O-O 18. Ne2: Get my knight to a more useful square but I missed the fork.
moves.19... Rf7 20. Qxb4: And I get a bishop for free.
moves.21. Qa4: Now the knight can't threaten my queen for at least three moves.
I was afraid of an attack down the f-file and didn't recognize the purpose of that move.
moves.25. Nf4: So I tried to shore things up a bit.
moves.26... Rc2: That's when I saw my chance. If I could just free my bishop without tipping my hand to black.
moves.27. exf5: Taking the pawn on f5 looks innocent enough.
moves.27... Rxf5: Too bad it's mate in three because I have a chance to gain some material by forking the rooks.
moves.28... Rf8: Notice that this forced move moves the rook away from guarding the d5 square.
